PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A Way of Experiencing in the Person

NO. 2

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to perceive a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use every bit of space if there is not sufficient space to answer the question. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Test What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Really Do All That Century?" If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (X).

(X) All Questionnaires

(X) Pioneer health conditions

(X) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation

(X) Pioneer housing

(X) Pioneer education and churchwork

(X) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EMIGRANTS: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and places names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct, as you have given it, or if you would rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Mrs. Susanne Taylor
2. Your address: April 15th, 1903
3. Date: April 15th, 1903
4. Where were you born? (Give name or place and country) Port Elgin, Ont.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) March, 1903
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. Port Elgin, Ont., 1895-1903

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or if you may use "I was a small child".)
   "I was in my teens", etc.)
   Eight years old

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   My father had been raised on a farm near Port Elgin, and thought farming would be a good occupation for himself and his three brothers, who then myself.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)
    My father had come to Western Canada on a farm near Port Elgin. My mother had a sister at Oxford, Ont.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought we were coming entirely too soon.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

The dad went with mother, Agnes and I. We went to Okotoks.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We took train and bus from Okotoks to Calgary.

14. What incidents of the Journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement).

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

With our aunt and uncle, who had homesteaded in 1908.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Ox Town district lot 7, near the old school house.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We moved to Kindersley in 1910, homesteaded. Sepia, homesteaded.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My father farmed at Ox Town/1909-1910. Returned to work in the town as a team driver.

19. Any other stories you would like to add in our book.

Absolutely nothing to add in our book. Just wish to thank all those who helped us and our family during those years.

20. Any advice you would give to others coming to Western Canada?

Work hard and save money. Don't rush into buying things you don't need.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They thought we were leaving civilization so we had clothes and food enough to last for about three years.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

My Dad went with the ear of settlers. Age 12 years 6 months.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We came March and stayed April by train to Okotoks, then west with team and wagon. It was at $200 round trip in the west.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents etc.)

I remember waiting for our train in Toronto. Mother was very upset watching for a lonely young man. Father said he liked Aunt of how traveling would affect our life. Brother, she liked mother into getting better. I remember sleeping in an open car. We enjoyed the trip very much. Mother said the train was too late leaving Brandon. Mother was worried thinking for water would go back home and no one would help us all three children in the station. We were tired of our lives and mother brought us a lunch in the station.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

With our Aunt and Uncle, who had homesteaded in the Oxbow district not far from the North Dakota border.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

My father bought a quarter section near Okotoks in 1903.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We moved to Kindersley in 1910. Married there.

Poveshell, Ontario, briefly. Newbold, Saskatchewan.

On a ranch on the Smith Road near address.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

My father farmed at Okotoks 1903 to 1910. Married to Kindersley where he and my three brothers took up homesteads. We have mostly farmed but worked on a farm in the spring and fall. Married a housewife twice and worked on a ranch after 1914 crop failure.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? Why was much of travel necessary?

We had farming of about normal, people had horses and wagons loaded of supplies and livestock and living a life of hard work and frugality.

---

Two of my brothers are farming the original homestead along with greatly added acreage at Kindersley. One brother lives in Saskatoon, two others in Edmonton, one in Drumheller, Alta., two are housewives from Okotoks. Mother and Dad are buried at Kindersley.

---

In these early pioneer days there was much more primitive living at Kindersley than there is today. We had horses and wagons, but we didn't have electricity or telephones. We lived in a small town called Kindersley, which was very different from what it is today.

We were very scarce of privacy, living in close quarters with our neighbors. We didn't have many luxuries, but we were happy and enjoyed everything very much.

31. What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail orders since the telephone appeared.
   *I remember the first order we placed where we were living at Oxford. We went there and got a new high chair for the baby. We were delighted with the order. When at Kindredly moved into the full-size furniture, we ordered large orders and had them delivered by mail order. Clothing, shoes, and other things were purchased by mail order. These are supplies dealt with much more frequently now and most nearly as much as they were purchased by mail order. We explored the idea of buying everything by mail order, but we found it too expensive that way.*

   *We had a telephone at Oxford 1909, at Kindredly 1916.*

33. When did you make up your mind after trying it out? Then did you make this decision?
